title: At $18 Million, This is Brooklyn’s Most Expensive Home on the Market
text:
An 8,500-square-foot townhouse in Brooklyn Heights, New York, listed Tuesday for $18 million, making it the most expensive residential listing in Brooklyn. The next highest listing comes in at $15.9 million, according to Zillow.



Records show that the seller is an entity controlled by a law firm, which purchased the townhouse in 2008 for $10.8 million. Nancy Giddins with Brown Harris Stevens has the listing.



The five-story townhouse is currently configured as a four-story residence spanning the top floors plus a separate garden-floor unit, which can be rented out or used for guests, or entertaining, according to the listing. Outside, there is a separate carriage house with a one-bedroom, one-bathroom apartment, with a garage, a full kitchen, a theater on the basement level and an attached, glass-enclosed shower.



The entire property runs the full width of the block, from Remsen Street through to Grace Court Alley, Ms. Giddins said.

The main house comprises seven bedrooms, eight bathrooms, and three half-bathrooms, total. The four-story unit encompasses five bedrooms and seven bathrooms, as well as built-in closets, a private fourth-floor terrace and a private roof deck.



The garden-level apartment features a custom-built kitchen that opens to a private terrace and garden and a game room in the basement with a jukebox, a pool table and a foosball table, according to the listing.

The home is also adorned with unique architectural details, including 12-foot floor-to-ceiling windows in the living room and arched doorways. The house was built in 1915 and updated over the years by the current owners, Ms. Giddins said. Many of its original details have been restored, including the crown moldings, fireplace mantles, and marquetry flooring, according to the listing. The owners also updated the kitchen and bathrooms to fit modern living, Ms. Giddins said.

Correction: The main house has seven bedrooms, eight bathrooms and three half-bathrooms. The numbers were incorrect in a previous version.
